Award.AwardTitle: Backwater Control of the Morphodynamics of Delta Growth
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. John Shaw has been granted an NSF Earth Sciences postdoctoral fellowship to determine the effect of backwater flow on the depositional environment of river deltas. This research and education plan will take place at the University of Wyoming. The investigation will include laboratory-scale experiments which facilitate detailed measurement of delta properties, and outcrop study of ancient delta deposits exposed in Wyoming and Utah. By forcing experimental deltas to build under a rigid lid rather than a free surface, experiments will more closely resemble the low-slope deltas found at the mouth of the Mississippi River, as opposed than steeper-slope commonly realized in delta experiments. Dr. Shaw and interested undergraduate and graduate students will take morphologic and stratigraphic relationships drawn from the experimental analysis and apply them to rock outcrops of river deltas, with the goal of quantifying the size and shape of ancient delta systems. As part of the educational component of the plan, Dr. Shaw will create an river delta exhibit for the University of Wyoming Geological Museum, using ancient delta formations found in Wyoming and specifically in nearby Native American Reservations.

River deltas support large human populations that benefit from productive ecosystems and transportation corridors, but are at risk from the hazards of storms and land loss associated with relative sea level rise. By investigating the effect of important variables (channel depth and slope) on delta morphology and stratigraphy, we will gain further knowledge regarding the depositional architecture of deltas, and better insight into how they will change in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF post-doctoral fellowship saught to investigate the influence on sea level on erosional depositional patterns in river deltas. River deltas are important land forms because hundreds of millions of people inhabit river deltas, and they are expected to dynamically change over the next century with rising sea levels and a changing climate. By investigating erosion and deposition using both theory and experiments, the goal was to develop models to enhance prediction of future delta change, and to improve the interpretation of ancient delta stratigraphy. Over the fellowship, we developed two such models.

Our first approach was to develop a physical theory for controls on erosion and deposition in all sedimentary environments from first principals. Using arguments for the conservation of water mass and water momentum, we developed theory to discern whether erosion and deposition were brought on by changes in water depth, or changes in the water surface slope, and that the relative influence could be quantified by the dimensionless Backwater Number. This theory was published in Journal of Geophysical Research - Earth Surface. The work shows that in natural river delta lobes (as well as meandering rivers and dunes on channel beds) erode and deposit due to flow accelerations brought on by changing water depth, rather than water surface slope. This result has implications for predicting the future erosion and deposition on modern river deltas, and for estimating environmental parameters in delta stratigraphy, both on Earth and Mars.

Our second approach was to build laboratory scale river deltas to investigate erosion and deposition, specifically the formation of islands and channels. In total, we ran 40 delta experiments (each roughly 5 hours) under a wide variety of boundary conditions. Six of these experiments were performed and analyzed by undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Arkansas, providing a broader impact to the scientific advance. Using the data from these experiments, we developed a new model of the distance to island formation, based exclusively on the conservation of fluid mass. This model predicted experimental results to within a factor of 3 for deltas ranging over an order of magnitude in size. Further, the model could predict the location of islands with the same precision on field scale deltas three orders of magnitude larger than the experiments (see figure). 

In conclusion, the results from this NSF post-doctoral fellowship provide means to simplify how river deltas are investigated, providing greater certainty about predictions of future delta change in the face of rising sea levels and reduced sediment supply. In addition, the models provide new means for estimating aspects of ancient environmentals preserved in river delta stratigraphy.
